Dehydration of glycerin to acrolein over H3PW12O40 heteropolyacid catalyst supported on silica-alumina Tae Hun Kang a Jung Ho Choi a Yongju Bang a Jaekyeong Yoo a Ji Hwan Song a Wangrae Joe b Jun Seon Choi b In Kyu Song a ⁎ a School of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Institute of Chemical Processes, Seoul National University, Shinlim-dong, Kwanak-ku, Seoul 151-744, South Korea School of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Institute of Chemical Processes, Seoul National University Shinlim-dong, Kwanak-ku Seoul 151-744 South Korea b LG Chem. Ltd., Moonji-dong, Yuseong-Gu, Daejeon 305-380, South Korea LG Chem. Ltd. Moonji-dong, Yuseong-Gu Daejeon 305-380 South Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 2 880 9227; fax: +82 2 889 7415. Graphical abstract A series of tungstophosphoricacid (H3PW12O40) catalysts supported on silica-alumina (SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100)) with different SiO2 content (X, mol%) were prepared, and they (H3PW12O40/SA-X) were applied to the gas-phase dehydration of glycerin to acrolein. The effect of support composition on the physicochemical properties and catalytic activities of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts was investigated. Total acidity and Brønsted acidity of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts determined from pyridine-adsorbed in situ FT-IR spectroscopy measurements showed volcano-shaped trends with respect to SiO2 content. Among the catalysts, H3PW12O40/SA-50 exhibited the largest total acidity while H3PW12O40/SA-85 showed the largest Brønsted acidity. The results of 27Al NMR spectroscopy analyses of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =15, 30, 50, 70, and 85) catalysts clearly demonstrated that Brønsted acidity of the catalysts was proportional to the amount of AlIV species. It was revealed that yield for acrolein increased with increasing Brønsted acidity rather than total acidity of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts. Among the catalysts tested, H3PW12O40/SA-85 with the largest Brønsted acidity showed the highest yield for acrolein. A synergistic effect between H3PW12O40 and SA-85 for H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst was also observed in the dehydration of glycerin to acrolein. Moreover, the catalytic performance of regenerated H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst was almost recovered compared to that of fresh H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst. Keywords Heteropolyacid Silica-alumina Dehydration of glycerin Acrolein Brønsted acidity 1 Introduction Acrolein has attracted much attention due to its applicability as a chemical intermediate for the synthesis of acrylic acid, methionine, and super-absorber polymers [1]. Acrolein has been conventionally produced by the partial oxidation process of petroleum-based propylene over multi-component metal oxide catalysts [2]. However, gas-phase dehydration of bio-based glycerin over acid catalyst has garnered recent attraction as a promising alternative route for acrolein production due to several economical and environmental benefits, with increasing concerns about fossil fuel depletion and global warming problem [2–4]. Several solid acid catalysts such as zeolites [5] and phosphates [6] have been investigated as catalysts for gas-phase dehydration of glycerin. However, a previous work [7] revealed that acid-catalyzed dehydration of glycerin suffered from catalyst deactivation and low catalytic activity due to coke formation and considerable activation energy, respectively. Heteropolyacids (HPAs) are early transition metal-oxygen anion clusters that possess much stronger Brønsted acid than other acids such as zeolites, metal oxides, and concentrated sulfuric acid [8,9]. HPAs have been widely employed as catalysts in various acid-catalyzed reactions such as dehydration of glycerin [10], hydration of alkenes [11], and dehydration of alcohols [12]. However, low surface area (<10m2/g) of HPAs is a main drawback to maintain the catalytic performance during a long-time reaction under harsh environments. To overcome this problem, HPAs supported on porous materials with high surface area such as silica, alumina, zirconia, and carbon were investigated as a catalyst for acid-catalyzed reactions. Recently, it has been reported that tungstophosphoricacid (H3PW12O40) catalyst supported on alumina [13] or zirconia [14] showed an excellent catalytic activity in the dehydration of glycerin. In this work, silica-alumina was employed as a benign support for H3PW12O40 in the dehydration of glycerin due to its outstanding physicochemical properties such as high surface area, large pore volume, and excellent acid property [15–17]. Gas-phase dehydration of glycerin to acrolein was carried out over H3PW12O40 catalysts supported on silica-alumina (SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100)) with different SiO2 content (X, mol%). The prepared catalysts were characterized by ICP-AES, FT-IR, XRD, 31P MAS NMR, and nitrogen adsorption–desorption analyses. Pyridine-adsorbed in situ FT-IR spectroscopy analyses were conducted to examine the acid properties of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts. 27Al NMR measurements were also conducted to elucidate the acid properties of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =15, 30, 50, 70, and 85) catalysts. The effect of support composition on the catalytic performance in the dehydration of glycerin was investigated. A correlation between acid property and yield for acrolein was then established and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts A series of silica-alumina supports with different SiO2 content were prepared by a sol–gel method [10]. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, Sigma–Aldrich) was dissolved in distilled water, and pH of the solution was adjusted to 2.0 with nitric acid. The TEOS solution was vigorously stirred at 40°C for 1h. Aluminum nitrate nonahydrates (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Junsei Chem.) was separately dissolved in distilled water, and the solution was then added into the TEOS solution. The mixed solution was stirred at 40°C for 1h. Ammonium hydroxide solution (NH4OH, Sigma–Aldrich) was added into the mixed solution at a constant rate to form a hydrogel at pH 8.5. The hydrogel was further aged at 40°C for 1h, and subsequently, it was filtered, washed, and dried at 100°C for 10h. The resulting white solid was finally calcined at 550°C for 3h. The prepared silica-alumina supports were denoted as SA-X (X =15, 30, 50, 70, and 85), where X represented SiO2 content (mol%) in silica-alumina. Pure alumina (SA-0) and silica (SA-100) supports were also prepared by the similar methods described above. H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method using an aqueous solution of tungstophosphoricacid (H3PW12O40). Content of H3PW12O40 in all the supported catalysts was fixed at 10.0wt%. The impregnated solid catalysts were dried at 80°C for 10h, and then they were calcined at 300°C for 3h. The prepared catalysts were denoted as H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100). 2.2 Characterization of catalysts Infrared spectra of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts were obtained using a Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, Nicolet 6700) with a diffuse reflectance accessory. Chemical compositions of the catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) analyses (Shimadzu, ICP-1000IV). Nitrogen adsorption–desorption experiments (BEL Japan, BELSORP-mini II) were conducted to examine the textural properties, and pore size distributions were determined by BJH (Barret–Joyner–Hallender) method. X-ray diffractograms were obtained (Rigaku, D-MAX2500-PC) using Cu-Kα radiation operated at 50kV and 100mA. Structural state of H3PW12O40 was confirmed by 31P magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) spectroscopy analyses (Bruker, AVANCE 400 WB). Aluminum coordination state was examined by a 400-MHz solid state 27Al nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer (Bruker, AVANCE 400 WB) at frequencies of 104.3MHz. Acid properties of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts were determined by pyridine-adsorbed in situ FT-IR spectroscopy measurements. Each catalyst (0.03g) was pressed into a pellet with a radius of 0.65cm. The pellet was preheated at 300°C for 1h with a stream of He (40ml/min) in a tubular quartz reactor. After cooling the pellet to 50°C, pyridine vapor (20ml) was pulsed into the reactor with a stream of He (40ml/min) until the acid sites were saturated with pyridine. The reactor was then evacuated at 50°C for 1h. Brønsted acidity and Lewis acidity were determined from IR spectra of pyridine-adsorbed catalysts at 50°C within spectral range of 1600–1400cm−1. 2.3 Gas-phase dehydration of glycerin Gas-phase dehydration of glycerin was carried out in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor under atmospheric pressure. Each catalyst (0.1g) was charged into a tubular pyrex reactor. The reactor was preheated with a stream of nitrogen carrier gas (30ml/min) at 275°C for 0.5h to achieve steady-state operation. Glycerin feed (7mol% aqueous solution, 0.042mol/h) was sufficiently vaporized by passing through a pre-heating zone, and it was continuously fed into the reactor together with a stream of nitrogen (30ml/min). The reaction was carried out at 275°C for 10h. The reaction products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (Younglin, YL6100 GC) and a capillary column (Agilent, DB-5MS, 60m×0.32mm). 1,4-Dioxane was used as an internal standard for quantitative calculation. Conversion of glycerin, selectivity for product, and yield for product were calculated according to the following equations. (1) Conversion of glycerin ( % ) = mole of glycerin inlet − mole of glycerin outlet mole of glycerin inlet × 100 (2) Selectivity for product ( % ) = mole of product outlet mole of glycerin inlet − mole of glycerin outlet × 100 (3) Yield for product ( % ) = mole of product outlet mole of glycerin inlet × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Fig. 1 shows the FT-IR spectra of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100) catalysts. H3PW12O40/SA-0 exhibited broad bands within the range of 1250–700cm−1, corresponding to the disordered metastable spinel structure of γ-Al2O3 [18]. H3PW12O40/SA-100 showed broad bands at around 1250–1000cm−1 (asymmetric stretching SiOSi), 800cm−1 (symmetric stretching SiOSi), and a weak shoulder band at around 974cm−1 (surface OH group), which were attributed to SiO2 framework [19,20]. FT-IR spectra of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =15, 30, 50, 70, and 85) catalysts exhibited characteristics of both γ-Al2O3 and SiO2. The intensity of IR bands at around 1250–1000cm−1 corresponding to asymmetric stretching vibrations of SiOSi bonding increased with increasing SiO2 content. In addition, IR bands due to asymmetric stretching vibrations of SiOSi bonding shifted to higher frequencies with increasing SiO2 content, which were attributed to an increased cross-linking of SiOSi network [21,22]. It has been reported that H3PW12O40 exhibited four characteristic IR bands at 1080cm−1 (PO), 983cm−1 (WO), 890cm−1 (WOc W), and 812cm−1 (WOe W) [23]. However, the characteristic IR bands corresponding to H3PW12O40 were not clearly observed in the H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts, because the characteristic IR bands of H3PW12O40 were overlapped with large and broad IR bands of supports [20]. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100) catalysts. H3PW12O40/SA-0 showed XRD peaks at 2θ =45° and 67° indicative of γ-Al2O3 structure [24]. H3PW12O40/SA-100 showed a broad peak at 2θ =22° corresponding to amorphous SiO2 framework. XRD patterns of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =15, 30, 50, 70, and 85) catalysts showed both γ-Al2O3 and amorphous SiO2 diffraction characteristics with weak intensity. Intensity of diffraction peak attributed to SiO2 framework increased with increasing SiO2 content, in good agreement with the FT-IR results. However, H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts did not show the characteristic XRD peaks for H3PW12O40. The above results indicated that H3PW12O4O was finely dispersed on the supports [20]. 31P MAS NMR measurements were carried out to confirm the structural state of H3PW12O40. Fig. 3 shows the 31P MAS NMR spectra of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 50, 85, and 100) catalysts. 31P MAS NMR spectra showed three peaks due to different structural state of H3PW12O40; hydrated H3PW12O40 species (−15.5ppm), H3PW12O40 species interacting with surface acid sites of alumina (−13.9ppm), and lacunary species ([PW11O39]7−) or another fragmented forms of heteropolyanion (−11.6ppm) [25]. H3PW12O40 supported on SiO2-rich silica-alumina supports exhibited a peak at −15.5ppm, indicating that the primary structure of H3PW12O40 was retained as a hydrated form. Although H3PW12O40 supported on Al2O3-rich silica-alumina supports showed partially fragment species at −11.6ppm due to strong interaction with alumina surface, the primary structure of H3PW12O40 was still maintained as an interacted form with silica-alumina surface. Therefore, it can be said that no characteristic diffraction peaks (Fig. 2) for any heteropolyacid species indicate high dispersion of H3PW12O40 on the silica-alumina supports. Fig. 4 shows the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 50, 85, and 100) catalysts. H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts exhibited type-IV isotherm with H2 or H3 hysteresis loop. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts were similar to those of supports (not shown here), indicating that the mesoporous structure of supports was maintained even after the loading of H3PW12O40 on the supports. Surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . It was found that surface area of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts increased with increasing SiO2 content. However, pore volume and average pore diameter of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts did not show any noticeable trends with respect to SiO2 content. It was also observed that the measured SiO2 content was well consistent with the designed value. 3.2 Acid properties of catalysts Pyridine-adsorbed in situ FT-IR spectroscopy measurements were conducted to investigate the acid properties of the catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the pyridine-adsorbed in situ FT-IR spectra of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100) catalysts. All the catalysts exhibited IR bands corresponding to Brønsted acid sites (1545cm−1) and Lewis acid sites (1450cm−1). IR spectra at 1490cm−1 corresponding to both Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites were overlapped. Brønsted acidity and Lewis acidity of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts were quantitatively measured according to the method reported in the literature [26] as summarized in Table 2 . Total acidity was calculated as the sum of Brønsted acidity and Lewis acidity. Total acidity of the catalysts exhibited a volcano-shaped trend with respect to SiO2 content. Among the catalysts tested, H3PW12O40/SA-50 showed the largest total acidity. Brønsted acidity of the catalysts also showed a volcano-shaped trend with respect to SiO2 content. In this case, however, H3PW12O40/SA-85 showed the largest Brønsted acidity. H3PW12O40/SA-0 retained the smallest Brønsted acidity and the largest Lewis acidity. In addition, H3PW12O40/SA-100 showed very weak IR bands compared to the other catalysts (Fig. 5), resulting in quite small total and Brønsted acidities (Table 2). 3.3 Aluminum coordination state in the catalysts 27Al NMR measurements were conducted to elucidate the difference in acid properties of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =15, 30, 50, 70, and 85) catalysts. Fig. 6 shows the 27Al NMR spectra of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =15, 30, 50, 70, and 85) catalysts. All the 27Al NMR spectra exhibited three peaks because of different aluminum coordination states; tetrahedral-coordinated aluminum species (AlIV, 50–65ppm), pentahedral-coordinated aluminum species (AlV, 30–35ppm), and octahedral-coordinated aluminum species (AlVI, 0–7ppm). The amount of aluminum species determined from peak area of 27Al NMR spectra is summarized in Table 2. The amount of AlVI species decreased with increasing SiO2 content due to the increase of agglomeration of isolated Al framework during the formation of AlOAl bonds. However, the amount of AlIV species increased with increasing SiO2 content because of the substitution of Al3+ into Si4+ sites at tetrahedral SiO2 framework structure [27]. The amount of AlV species, which located at the interface between mixed silica-alumina and aluminum oxide phase [28], did not show a noticeable trend with respect to SiO2 content. It is interesting to note that Brønsted acidity of the catalysts showed the same trend with the amount of AlIV species (Table 2). It has been reported that Brønsted acid sites of silica-alumina are attributed to tetrahedral-coordinated Al cations in Si–O–Si network [27,28]. Therefore, Brønsted acidity of the catalysts increased with increasing SiO2 content and with increasing the amount of AlIV species. Among the catalysts, H3PW12O40/SA-85 with the largest amount of AlIV species showed the largest Brønsted acidity. It is believed that H3PW12O40/SA-0 showed the smallest Brønsted acidity and the largest Lewis acidity, because γ-Al2O3 retained only Lewis acid sites [29]. Moreover, it can be inferred that neutral silica support with partial surface silanol group [30] might be responsible for small total and Brønsted acidities of H3PW12O40/SA-100. Consequently, Brønsted acidity of the catalysts exhibited a volcano-shaped trend with respect to SiO2 content (Table 2), and H3PW12O40/SA-85 showed the largest Brønsted acidity. 3.4 Catalytic performance in the gas-phase dehydration of glycerin Gas-phase dehydration of glycerin to acrolein was carried out over H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100) catalysts. Fig. 7 shows the catalytic performance of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts with time on stream at 275°C. Conversion of glycerin, selectivity for product, and yield for acrolein after a 10h-reaction are summarized in Table 3 . According to the literature [5], acrolein was mainly produced during the reaction, while hydroxyacetone and allyl alcohol were produced as by-products. It is known that dehydration of glycerin follows elimination mechanism, and the acid catalyst initiates the formation of primary and secondary carbocations [2]. Secondary carbocation is more stable than primary carbocation due to the thermodynamic effect. Therefore, acrolein is mainly produced through two-step dehydration via secondary carbocation. Hydroxyacetone produced from primary carbocation is the major by-product, while other compounds such as allyl alcohol, 1,2-propanediol, acetaldehyde, and acetic acid are the possible minor by-products in the dehydration of glycerin [1,7]. It was revealed that yield for acrolein increased in the order of H3PW12O40/SA-0<H3PW12O40/SA-100<H3PW12O40/SA-15<H3PW12O40/SA-30<H3PW12O40/SA-50<H3PW12O40/SA-70<H3PW12O40/SA-85. H3PW12O40/SA-0 and H3PW12O40/SA-100 exhibited lower yield for acrolein than H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =15, 30, 50, 70, and 85) catalysts. The trend of yield for acrolein of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100) was not directly correlated with the trend of total acidity of the catalysts. However, the trend of yield for acrolein of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100) was well consistent with the trend of Brønsted acidity of the catalysts. Fig. 8 shows the correlation between yield for acrolein after a 10h-reaction over H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100) catalysts and Brønsted acidity of the catalysts. It should be noted that yield for acrolein increased with increasing Brønsted acidity of the catalysts. This result was well consistent with the result of previous works [31–33] in a sense that Brønsted acid sites strongly affected the acrolein formation in the dehydration of glycerin. In case of Brønsted acid sites, migration of proton from the catalyst to internal oxygen of glycerin is facile due to the absence of steric effect. Therefore, protonation of internal oxygen leads to the formation of acrolein via secondary carbocations. However, interaction of glycerin with Lewis acid sites can be affected by steric constraints due to the electronic structure of Lewis acid sites, and terminal oxygen of glycerin reacts with catalyst more easily than internal oxygen of glycerin. As a result, hydroxyacetone is mainly produced on the Lewis acid sites via primary carbocations. Among the catalysts tested, H3PW12O40/SA-85 with the largest Brønsted acidity showed the highest yield for acrolein. Therefore, it is concluded that Brønsted acidity of the catalysts is an important factor determining the catalytic performance in the dehydration of glycerin to acrolein. Catalytic performance of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts gradually decreased with time on stream during the 10h-reaction. The spent H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts were collected after the 10h-reaction for CHNS analyses. The amount of carbon deposition in the spent catalysts determined by CHNS analyses is summarized in Table 3. The result showed that severe coke formed during the reaction blocked the active sites of the catalysts, resulting in catalyst deactivation. Moreover, carbon balance was less than 100% due to the carbon deposition derived from oligomerization of glycerin [34], polymerization of acrolein [35], and formation of undetectable cyclic C6-compounds [36]. Fig. 9 shows the conversion of glycerin and yield for acrolein over H3PW12O40/SA-85, H3PW12O40, and SA-85 with time on stream at 275°C. It is noteworthy that conversion of glycerin and yield for acrolein over H3PW12O40/SA-85 were much higher than those over H3PW12O40 and SA-85. This means that H3PW12O40 and SA-85 synergistically affected the catalytic performance of H3PW12O40/SA-85. Because of the complexity of the reaction mechanism of glycerin dehydration, deconvolution of the synergistic effect was not a simple task. However, it is inferred that silica-alumina with moderate Brønsted acidity and high surface area not only provided additional active sites for dehydration of glycerin but also led to high dispersion of HPA, resulting in outstanding catalytic performance of H3PW12O40/SA-85. It was also revealed that Brønsted acidity of H3PW12O40 (0.62mmol-pyridine/g-cat.) was larger than that of SA-85 (0.53mmol-pyridine/g-cat.) (not shown here). Although initial activity of SA-85 was higher than that of H3PW12O40, yield for acrolein after a 10h-reaction over SA-85 (10.1%) was lower than that of H3PW12O40 (12.6%) (Fig. 9), in good agreement with the main conclusion of this work in a sense that large Brønsted acidity of the catalyst was more favorable for dehydration of glycerin to acrolein (Fig. 8). 3.5 Regeneration test of H3PW12O40/SA-85 Regeneration of deactivated catalyst is an important issue in the catalytic dehydration of glycerin [1]. Therefore, the regeneration test for H3PW12O40/SA-85 was conducted in order to investigate the stability and reusability of the catalyst. Fig. 10 shows the temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) profile of spent H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst used for 10h-reaction. During the TPO measurement, the desorbed CO2 was monitored using a GC-MSD (Agilent, MSD-6890N GC). The TPO profile of spent H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst showed two peaks at 429°C and 536°C, indicating that two kinds of carbonaceous materials (soft coke and hard coke) were formed during the 10h-reaction. Based on this result, the regeneration temperature was chosen to be 500°C. The regeneration of spent H3PW12O40/SA-85 was done with a mixed stream of nitrogen (30ml/min) and oxygen (10ml/min) at 500°C for 10h. Fig. 11 shows the yield for acrolein over fresh H3PW12O40/SA-85 and regenerated H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalysts in the dehydration of glycerin with time on stream at 275°C. It should be noted that the catalytic performance of regenerated H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst was almost the same as that of fresh H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst during the 10h-reaction. Furthermore, the amount of carbon species on the regenerated H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst determined by CHNS analysis was less than 0.1%. This indicates that H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst was completely regenerated under our regeneration conditions and that H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst showed excellent reusability in the dehydration of glycerin to acrolein. 3.6 Structural stability of regenerated catalyst 31P MAS NMR measurements were carried out to investigate the structural state of fresh, spent, and regenerated H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalysts. Fig. 12 shows the 31P MAS NMR spectra of fresh, spent, and regenerated H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalysts. 31P MAS NMR analyses revealed that fresh, spent, and regenerated H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalysts exhibited a single peak at −15.5ppm due to the hydrated form of H3PW12O40. This result clearly indicates that the primary structure of H3PW12O40 in the H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst was maintained even after the catalytic reaction and regeneration process. Therefore, it is concluded that H3PW12O40/SA-85 served as a stable, reusable, and highly active catalyst for the dehydration of glycerin. 4 Conclusions Gas-phase dehydration of glycerin to acrolein was carried out over H3PW12O40 catalysts supported on silica-alumina supports (SA-X) with different SiO2 content (X, mol%). Total acidity and Brønsted acidity of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts determined from pyridine-adsorbed in situ FT-IR spectroscopy showed volcano-shaped trends with respect to SiO2 content. Among the catalysts, H3PW12O40/SA-50 and H3PW12O40/SA-85 exhibited the largest total acidity and Brønsted acidity, respectively. 27Al NMR spectroscopy analyses of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =15, 30, 50, 70, and 85) catalysts revealed that Brønsted acidity of the catalysts increased with increasing the amount of AlIV species. It was found that the catalytic performance of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100) in the dehydration of glycerin was closely related to Brønsted acidity of the catalysts rather than total acidity of the catalysts. The catalytic performance of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100) catalysts increased with increasing Brønsted acidity of the catalysts. Among the catalysts tested, H3PW12O40/SA-85 with the largest Brønsted acidity showed the highest yield for acrolein. Thus, Brønsted acidity of the catalysts served as an important role in the catalytic dehydration of glycerin to acrolein. A synergistic effect between H3PW12O40 and SA-85 for H3PW12O40/SA-85 was also observed in the dehydration of glycerin. Thus, H3PW12O40/SA-85 served as a stable, reusable, and highly active catalyst for the dehydration of glycerin. Acknowledgements This work was supported by LG Chemical Corporation. coredata.dc:description: A series of tungstophosphoricacid (H3PW12O40) catalysts supported on silica-alumina (SA-X (X =0, 15, 30, 50, 70, 85, and 100)) with different SiO2 content (X, mol%) were prepared, and they (H3PW12O40/SA-X) were applied to the gas-phase dehydration of glycerin to acrolein. The effect of support composition on the physicochemical properties and catalytic activities of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts was investigated. Total acidity and Brønsted acidity of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts determined from pyridine-adsorbed in situ FT-IR spectroscopy measurements showed volcano-shaped trends with respect to SiO2 content. Among the catalysts, H3PW12O40/SA-50 exhibited the largest total acidity while H3PW12O40/SA-85 showed the largest Brønsted acidity. The results of 27Al NMR spectroscopy analyses of H3PW12O40/SA-X (X =15, 30, 50, 70, and 85) catalysts clearly demonstrated that Brønsted acidity of the catalysts was proportional to the amount of AlIV species. It was revealed that yield for acrolein increased with increasing Brønsted acidity rather than total acidity of H3PW12O40/SA-X catalysts. Among the catalysts tested, H3PW12O40/SA-85 with the largest Brønsted acidity showed the highest yield for acrolein. A synergistic effect between H3PW12O40 and SA-85 for H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst was also observed in the dehydration of glycerin to acrolein. Moreover, the catalytic performance of regenerated H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst was almost recovered compared to that of fresh H3PW12O40/SA-85 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Dehydration of glycerin to acrolein over H3PW12O40 heteropolyacid catalyst supported on silica-alumina
